[h1] Castle Crashers [/h1] 
Castle Crashers is a delightful and action-packed multiplayer beat 'em up game that delivers hours of fun with friends. With its charming art style, hilarious humor, and simple yet addictive gameplay, players embark on an epic journey to rescue princesses and defeat evil forces. The game's variety of characters, weapons, and abilities keep every playthrough fresh and entertaining. Whether you're battling enemies solo or teaming up with friends for cooperative mayhem, Castle Crashers offers a whimsical and exciting adventure that is sure to bring smiles to everyone's faces.

READ THE FULL REVIEW (Steam has a word limit) HERE: https://gemsimov.com/game-reviews/f/castle-crashers-%7C-a-review
--
Simple review details - I rank games on an out of 10 basis, granting up to 3 points in 3 categories, as well as a last, single point from my own self, depending on my experience with it.

GAMEPLAY

Castle Crashers is a side-scrolling beat-em-up, and it is somewhat 2D, somewhat 3D, but it struggles with its 3D field implementation, causing issues with hit detection and combat flow. The controls involve opportunities for movement, attacks, and interactions, overall emphasizing beat-em-up mechanics.

 While the game offers polished elements, such as the ability to stagger enemies and thus perform impressive combos, the addition of the third dimension complicates combat, leading to inconsistent interactions. The game introduces features like stat allocation, mounted combat, and unique pets, but falls short of addressing core issues, hindering the overall gameplay experience and preventing it from reaching its full potential.
2/3

PRESENTATION

This game is the internet‚Äôs culture from the haydays of flash, from the 2010s. It features visuals that are particularly distinct, drawing from the aesthetics of that aforementioned era, and looks fantastic. There‚Äôs humor, and it‚Äôs crass, and it  includes elements like poop, farts, and gore, reflecting the tone of content from platforms like Newgrounds. 

 The stylized look uses thick black lines to outline interactable elements, and the music and sound effects contribute to a very high-quality presentation. The story is conveyed through dialogue-free cutscenes with expressive animations. While the crass humor may not be universally appreciated, the overall quality of this thing, when it comes to how it is presented, is top-notch.
3/3

STORY

In this game, the Player, along with up to three friends, takes on the role of a knight (or a set of knights) partying in the barracks, when their celebration is abruptly interrupted. A stranger crashes in, dies, and reveals that the castle is under attack. The King's magical crystal has been stolen by a wizard-ish figure who is also abducting the king's daughters. The knights embark on a quest to save the princesses, recover the crystal, and face various challenges in different lands. The story is minimal, typical of flash games, serving a basic conceptual purpose.
1/3

Legendary Point

Does this game get the legendary point, so craved and wanted by all and none at the same time?

I am inclined to say yes , because this game truly reminds me of the glory days of flash, of those games with the beefy purple guy with a chainsaw cleaving through hundreds of goons, of this rampant age of obscurity filled with wonder and the unknown‚Ä¶ But at the same time I know better than to do that. While Castle Crashers is a near timeless remnant of that age, the age has come and gone, and it should not be the reason I approve of this game. So no, Castle Crashers does not get the Legendary Point. 0/1

CONCLUSION

6/10. Castle Crashers is a very good game to play with friends. It is also a decent game to play by oneself, but I'd only recommend it to fans of side-scrollers and beat-em-ups, as well as folks who were fans of flash games.

I tuck it under my belt, safe from the bag of mediocrity, but sporting more dust than is proper.
--

Castle Crashers is an old beat em up from the 360 days I do genuinely like playing with friends but solo not so much. Too much of the combat is centered around enemies locking you down with ranged weapons keeping you from getting up by being on both sides of you at all times and always moving the perfect distance away when approaching them only to be shot in the back by another enemy. Other beat em ups don't pull schiesty crap like that and still offer a fun challenge and in this one "trapping you" underneath bullcrap like that is commonplace.  I love the character roster and there's a great many people to choose from and I would to have loved to play as so many of them....if they weren't all locked behind beating the game or playing Insane mode not counting the few you unlock behind arenas. There are over 30 characters in total and who in there right mind is beating this game over 10 times to unlock everyone? Ridiculous. Insane mode is a mode you unlock with the character you beat the game with. It makes the game harder and you unlock more weapons and characters through this mode. Im all for more difficulty but this mode doesn't even seem real and it should be a solid lesson what never to do as it doesn't offer proper challenge and seeks only to frustrate the player and artificially fatten the time you play it tremendously while not offering any sort of compensation or satisfaction that you had done anything at all. In Insane mode all enemies and bosses get 10X health and do 10X the damage except for a few select bosses because of they were beefed any more they would be too much. In order to survive Insane mode you must learn to permanently juggle and stay in the air permanently as you can be 2 hit by damn near EVERY enemy in the game now and some bosses will 1 shot you regardless of stats. All you can quaff did not make it from the original Castle Crashers wich is a bummer as I loved it and instead they replaced it with Back off Barbarian. A game mode where the timer goes slower than normal and you must survive board. The enemies get faster and faster as time goes on and it is fun and stressful but the mode ultimately just doesn't scratch that itch. All in all it is a game I will play again in the future with friends as I really do enjoy Behemoth's games but this one messed up in some serious ways.

game was meant to be only played in normal mode, as insane mode is too difficult to a point where its not challenging but just straight up frustrating. most enemies are given 10x their health and 5x their damage (with the exception of bosses getting 5x HP). You will have to learn how to juggle enemies which is continuously hitting them in the air from side to side of the screen for the entirety of this mode for like 5 mins for every wave of enemies you encounter and thus making the game feel repetitive. the starting enemies could kill you in 3 hits even at a high level. if you don't want to put up with the bullsh*t of insane mode, have fun missing out on 1/2 of the playable characters.

[h3]Back Off Barbarian (BOB)[/h3]
this minigame is entirely optional and not required for progression of the main story. BOB is pretty fun but execution was bad. the timer runs at 0.9x speed compared to real time and the worst thing (for achievement hunters) is that there's an achievement requiring you to survive for 2:30 mins (2:47 real time) which is unexcusable.

the game also forces you to [spoiler]kill your friends to see who is worthy of kissing the princesses[/spoiler]

Castle Crashers Is One Of The Best Games I've Ever Played. Castle Crashers is a 2D arcade adventure game which will have you playing again and again and again. 

Castle Crashers has many different characters to choose from. You can choose to play as an Ice Knight, a Fire Knight, a Love Knight and many, many more characters. Once you complete the game, you will unlock a new character depending on what character you beat the game with. With those newly unlocked characters, you can unlock even more characters by beating the game again which is why I said you'll be playing over and over again.

I will have a guide on my profile on how to unlock every character in the game. If your curious on how to, the link is right here:

Each Character has Magic, which are special abilities which vary from character to character. For example, the Lightning Knight will have lightning magic,  the Fire Knight will have Fire Magic and so on. Magic can be a very important part of this game, again depending on which character you play as. If you choose the Gray Knight, you'll probably not use magic much. But if you choose the Industrialist, magic is like the only thing you'll be using.

When playing Castle Crashers you'll find your character leveling up. Leveling up allows you to spend points you earn from leveling up towards a skill tree. The Skill Tree has 4 different paths to go down. Those Paths are Strength, Magic, Defense and Agility.

Strength is how much Damage Your Character does. 
Magic Allows you to deal more damage with said Magic and unlock new spells.
Defense Increases Your Hitpoints.
Agility Increases your speed and Archery skills.

Castle Crashers also utilizes items. Items will be very crucial to beating the game. One of those items being a bow. Your bow has infinite arrows, and can be upgraded by spending your level up points towards Agility in the skill tree. Another Vital Item is potions. You can buy Potions with Gold, which will restore all of your Hitpoints instantly on use. There are many more items to utilize, but I will let you discover those items and figure out their uses.

As you might've read in my last paragraph, this game has a gold system. Gold can buy you things like Potions, New Weapons, New Pets and much more. You can earn gold by multiple means, those being by killing enemies, bosses or just finding it.

Another aspect you might've just read about is pets. You can obtain pets by finding them or by buying them with your gold. Each pet does something different, and you can see what they do by going to the nurse at the pet keep. Some pets can give you items to heal, some pets fight the enemies with you and can do much more.

Finally, After you have beaten the game you unlock a new gamemode called Insane Mode. Insane Mode Is the hardest version of Castle Crashers there is. Only the most experienced players will beat Castle Crashers on Insane Mode.

In conclusion, Castle Crashers is an amazing game. If your going to get the game I suggest playing with up to 4 people. If you can't get anyone to play with you, you can play singleplayer just fine or you can play publicly. I first played Castle Crashers on the Playstation 3, and it was also the first ever video game I played and am still playing it.

Castle Crashers is a hand drawn, side-scrolling beat 'em up for up to four players. Playing as multi-coloured knights, your job is to defeat hundreds of baddies and bosses across a relatively short campaign in order to save the princesses. The addictive hook comes from the simple but satisfying combat, concise RPG elements, and a huge range of stat-changing weaponry to unlock. It's still uproarious good fun, and the new version remaster comes with an arena mode and mini game to flesh out the package.

PROS:
‚úì Beautiful hand-drawn cartoon style makes this a joy to watch
‚úì Enjoyable solo but better with friends
‚úì Multiple game modes are fun to play
‚úì Boss fights entertain as much as they challenge
‚úì Genuinely amusing sense of humor
‚úì Eclectic original soundtrack makes each level feel unique
‚úì Simple knockabout combat is still great fun
‚úì Tons of unlockable content to encourage replayability
‚úì Many playable characters in the game

CONS:
- Sometimes online play can be pretty broken
- Enemies can be overly damage spongy
- Can‚Äôt respec character stats
- Combat becomes repetitive over time

Such a beautiful game, one of my favorites. The gameplay seems rather easy, but it is still very entertaining. Unfortunately, the game isn't really long; it only takes 14 hours to beat the whole game. However, even if you complete the entire game, there are still a lot of secrets, weapons, and pets to collect. You can also unlock other characters besides the four knights. Playing with friends is an option too. There are also minigames and an area where you can fight against other players and bots. The game is amazing; I've played it several times, and the experience was always fantastic. The only thing that was off-putting, at least for me, were some unfunny jokes, but the rest is wonderful.
Kept all its charm after all this time, hasnt really aged in my opinion, one of the greatest of all time :)

Alright, brace yourself for a trip down memory lane, because your middle school years just called, and they want their pinnacle of human achievement back. Yeah, they're still holding onto that participation ribbon.

So, there I am, stumbling upon Castle Crashers, feeling all nostalgic like I've just unearthed the holy grail of side-scrolling joy. It's like Castlevania had a funky cousin who partied a bit too hard. The game not only met but exceeded my expectations. The graphics are as vibrant as a unicorn on an energy drink, and the gameplay? Well, it's like the Goldilocks of gaming ‚Äì just right. Easy enough to get the hang of, but not so monotonous that you start questioning your life choices.

And oh, the multiplayer! You can either gather the gang for a local shindig or venture into the wild world of online multiplayer. It's like a party where everyone's invited, except for that one guy who keeps ruining the vibe. Countless hours disappeared into unlocking characters and supercharging abilities, and let me tell you, it was time well spent.

Back in '08, Castle Crashers was my jam. The Behemoth didn't just stop there ‚Äì they injected more life into the game with DLC that introduced characters with abilities so unique they'd make a unicorn jealous. Animal orbs were like the entourage you never knew you needed, and weapons? Well, they were the secret sauce for character growth (or a challenge if you were feeling masochistic).

The game made its way to the Playstation Network in 2010, with exclusive mini-games in tow. Then came the Steam port ‚Äì a bit wonky on launch, but fear not, The Behemoth swooped in with updates, turning the chaos into pure, playable fun.

Verdict time, my fellow adventurers:

This is a hack and slash RPG that's been hugged by gamers of all stripes. Yeah, it might feel a tad repetitive as you level up, but the game throws curveballs like a stand-up comedian on roller skates. Fresh scenery, quirky opponents, and jokes that hit harder than a dad joke at a family reunion.

Playing with friends is the real deal here. So, if you're pondering the purchase, rally the troops. Completing the game is a quest in itself, and that's where the real fun lies ‚Äì unlocking characters, hunting down animal orbs, and upgrading weapons like a gaming Sherlock Holmes.

Thinking about trying it out? Download the demo. Budget tight? Wait for a discount or keep an eye on those Humble Indie Bundles. Oh, and can we all agree on one thing? Give us a sequel already! Castle Crashers 2 ‚Äì the world demands it.

Very fun game. Great for local multiplayer, and fun online. The campaign is short but well designed, and extremely replayable. Finally, insane mode provides a great challenge to those who seek to hone their mechanics and gain a level of mastery.

The remastered version of the game makes some interesting changes from the original Xbox360 version. TLDR: the base game has more content, and the DLCs have less. You can read further if you care to know the details...

I kinda like that they moved some of the old DLC characters into the base game, and made them unlockable by beating certain points of the game on Insane Mode. This actually provided some incentive to take a crack at Insane Mode, whereas before, it was just kinda an extra grind that you could do for no reward whatsoever. This also means that there is more content in the base game, and you don't need other DLCs or other games to unlock characters like the King, Necromancer, Alien, etc. (The only character you get from owning a separate game is Hatty Hattington if you own Battleblock Theatre).

That said, it feels weird that the only DLCs now are the ones that give you the Pink Knight and Blacksmith, and that there are no further extras you get in those DLCs (apart from two or three new weapons). It makes those DLCs feel too small, and less rewarding. If they are only going to give you one character each, then they should've moved those characters into the base game as well.

Overall, this game is endlessly entertaining, and I hope the recent remaster is a hint towards even more DLCs, or possibly a sequel. I know we would all love more characters and missions.

Very poorly designed game. The whole ethos of the game is that "more is more" where they throw a crap ton of enemies at you, who stun lock you almost permanently, yet the game is still quite easy because the devs must know about this design feature because to combat this, they also throw a crap ton of healing items your way. So in some ways, the game is simutaneously very easy and very frustrating.

Stunlocking aside, the combat system is also very boring. In fact, here's a breakneck speed on how to win virtually all but one or two encounters, whether that be standard or bosses: 1. Wait until you unlock the dash attack ability (which is very early on). 2. Turn yourself from a knight into a one man cavalry. 3. Zig zag vertically to avoid being stunlocked. 3. Dash attack the enemy as soon as you move (vertically) into their line of sight. 4. Repeat. This is easier and quicker than any other way of combating the enemy, mostly because, and again, this avoids being stunlocked. I know some will cry skill issue, but I don't think it's any lack of skill if you get hit but once, and then you can't move out of the way before the next bullet or arrow hits you, stunlocking you further.  So if this is a skill issue, then the solution to getting better is not getting hit at all, which isn't exactly realistic. 

Edit: I tried giving the game another few hours. There are so many other issue with the game in hindsight. The bosses are bullet sponges. I tried the magic system, and it sucks. I got the magic bar 75% (ish) of the way full and it does ONE damage to the later enemies. What is the fucking point? You know what? Not only do I not like this game, the game itself is trash. I've negatively reviewed other games before, but this game, this is the only one I have a bone to pick with. I honestly do not get why people like this game. Is it a "so bad it's good" type of thing? I'm genuinely curious.

Ingredients:
Milk - 0.5 l
Eggs - 3 pcs.
Vegetable oil - 1 tablespoon (+ for greasing the pan)
Flour - 250 g (slightly more than 1.5 cups with a capacity of 250 ml)
Sugar - 1 tablespoon
Salt - 1 pinch
Butter - 1 tablespoon
Mix the eggs, salt, sugar and stir with a mixer. Add the flour and pour in the milk. Beat the pancake batter to achieve a smooth consistency.

Pour vegetable oil into the dough so that the pancakes turn over easily at the time of frying and do not burn. Mix it up.

Preheat a frying pan and brush with oil.

Pour a small portion of the dough into the center of the pan. Immediately rotate the pan in a circle so that the dough is evenly distributed over the entire surface.

Fry thin pancakes over medium heat until browned on both sides. Turn the pancakes over carefully with a spatula. Lubricate the finished pancakes with butter immediately so that the edges are not dry, and the pancakes turn out to be tender.

Thin pancakes with milk can be served with jam, jam or condensed milk.
Enjoy your meal!

Great fun game that has ZERO hardware requirements. I could run this on a potato still get 60 fps. It's super easy to play as well with button mashing somehow managing to get me through several boss fights. Also, this game is so good I decided to make a cake. Here's the recipe.

Ingredients
Cake:
2 ‚Öõ cups all-purpose flour
2 cups white sugar
¬æ cup unsweetened cocoa powder
1 ¬Ω teaspoons baking powder
¬æ teaspoon baking soda
¬æ teaspoon salt
3 eggs
1 cup milk
¬Ω cup vegetable oil
1 tablespoon vanilla extract

Topping:
2 (20 ounce) cans pitted sour cherries
1 cup white sugar
¬º cup cornstarch
1 teaspoon vanilla extract

Frosting:
3 cups heavy whipping cream
‚Öì cup confectioners' sugar

Directions
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease and flour two 9-inch round cake pans; line bottoms with parchment paper. Place a medium bowl in the refrigerator to chill.

Whisk flour, sugar, cocoa, baking powder, baking soda, and salt together in a large bowl. Add eggs, milk, oil, and vanilla; beat until combined. Pour cake batter into the prepared pans.

Bake in the preheated oven until a toothpick inserted in the centers comes out clean, about 35 minutes. Cool layers in pans on wire racks for 10 minutes. Run a paring knife around edges to loosen and invert carefully onto racks to cool completely, 1 to 2 hours.

While cake layers bake, drain cherries for topping, reserving 1/2 cup juice. Combine reserved juice, cherries, sugar, and cornstarch in a 2-quart saucepan. Cook, stirring constantly, over low heat until thickened. Stir in vanilla. Let cool at room temperature for 30 minutes. Transfer to the refrigerator to cool completely before assembling cake.

Combine whipping cream and confectioners' sugar for frosting in the chilled medium bowl. Beat with an electric mixer at high speed until stiff peaks form.

Split each cake layer in half horizontally using a long serrated knife. Tear one layer into crumbs; set aside. Gently brush loose crumbs off top and sides of remaining layers using a pastry brush or your hands. Reserve 1 1/2 cups frosting for piping decorations on cake; set aside.

To assemble, place one cake layer on a cake plate. Spread with 1 cup frosting; top with 3/4 cup cherry topping. Top with second cake layer; repeat layers of frosting and cherry topping. Top with third cake layer and frost sides of cake.

Pat reserved cake crumbs onto sides of cake. Spoon reserved 1 1/2 cups frosting into a pastry bag fitted with a star decorator tip. Pipe around top and bottom edges of cake. Spoon remaining cherry topping on top of cake.

Store covered in the refrigerator until ready to serve.

In my opinion this game is a fun little romp, and good to play in short bursts or with your friends. While combat remains simple, it is competent, and the iconic cartoonish style art, along with the wide variety of locations your characters can go make the game a blast to play. Goons and frequent boss fights are varied, and there is even an occasional minigame to break things up. Additionally there are arenas, and a couple mini games you can pick from the main menu if you want to jump right into the action. This game is a blast and it‚Äôs a classic for a reason. Castle Crashers keeps you on your toes with it‚Äôs impressive and varied level design, and this competence, as well as it‚Äôs ease of access make this game a must play.

Combat is pretty bad, having to stop constantly when dealing with close range enemies due to other enemies farther away constantly shooting arrows at you to block them. Sure this makes you think more and deters mashing but it ends up backfiring anyway because for those who enjoy fast paced combat, this totally derails all combat completely, any momentum and adrenaline built up in the fight is thrown out the window because you have to keep stopping to block enemies nearly instantly switching from sword and shield to arrows being shot at you repeatedly. Yeah you have your own bow and arrow you can use or a ranged magic spell but by the time the animation is complete for actually using those attacks, you're already hit by the enemy arrows.

Then while going through stages, the devs thought it would be a good idea to keep delaying you while going through stages to watch UNSKIPPABLE cutscenes of things like an owl being afraid of noise in the background for a whole 10 seconds or more or a deer being scared of noise and taking a shit on the ground. Yeah it's a little funny the first few times but to force people to stop and watch this repeatedly, every time they have to repeat a stage gets annoying quick and shows a lack of respect for the player's time.  

I really wanted to enjoy this game, have something to sink lots of hours into but I can't recommend it with nonsense like this in the game.

Upon my initial encounter with Castle Crashers, which evoked nostalgic sentiments reminiscent of the classic side-scroller Castlevania, my curiosity was piqued. To my delight, the game surpassed my expectations. Its vibrant graphics add to the enjoyment, while the gameplay strikes a perfect balance‚Äîeasy to grasp yet dynamic enough to ward off monotony. The option to engage in either 4-player local or online multiplayer amplifies the experience. Countless hours have been joyously spent unlocking characters and maximizing abilities.

What captivates me most about the game is its accessibility; even a brief 5-minute session yields tangible accomplishments. Unlike other games demanding extensive time commitments, Castle Crashers ensures a good time without requiring an astronomical investment of time.

-={ 8 / 10 }=-
 Castle Crashers is a hilarious and addictive beat-em-up that shines brightest with friends. Its charming visuals, simple yet satisfying gameplay, and endless replayability make it a timeless classic. Just remember, chivalry isn't dead, but princesses probably are. So grab your chicken sword, gather your knights, and prepare to brawl your way to (maybe) happily ever after!

-={ GAMEPLAY }=-
Chaotic co-op joy: Team up with friends (or frenemies) for side-splitting mayhem and competitive princess-snatching.
A cast of quirky characters: Unlock and level up unique knights, each with their own fighting styles and hilarious personalities.
Beat-em-up bliss: Simple controls deliver satisfyingly crunchy combat, letting you juggle combos and unleash magic like a pro.
Replayability galore: Secret levels, hidden weapons, and endless challenges keep you coming back for more.
Potential court jester moments:

Repetitive gameplay: The core combat loop can get old after a while, especially solo.
Short campaign: Can be completed in a few hours, though DLC and challenges extend the fun.
Juvenile humor: Not for everyone's taste, with plenty of potty jokes and slapstick.

-={ PRICE }=-

I am a 45 -year -old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father raising my son, who is now 14 years old. My son won this game from his uncle, so we installed him on his computer and he started playing. Until the end of the week he had 24 hours in this game. This was horrible for me, because it was hard to find ways to spend time with my son, because he is always with friends or just watching Youtube. So I decided to do a Steam account and get this game to see if I could play beside him. I bought the game, chose my skin and world and started playing, but I was stuck in what you should do. I asked my son for help and he organized a game for me to participate. I loved it, because it was the best time I spent with my son since my wife died. Since then, this game has approached me and my son again and now we spend time together away from home as well. This game reminded me that there is fun in everything, and I brought many happy memories to me and my son.

This game came out for 360 in 2008, a year before Demon's Souls, 3 years before Dark Souls, and 5 years before Dark Souls 2. I say this because those games showed the world all the ways to make games hard but fair, and plenty of ways to make games hard and unfair. Castle Crashers didn't have these games as a reference, and it really shows, as the challenge in this game comes mostly comes from breaking the rules of what is or isn't fair every 30 seconds or so. The controls are clunky. Magic is mostly useless. If you're slightly off on the Y Axis you'll miss enemies completely. You're constantly getting pelted by arrowfire from multiple directions, but you can only ever block from one. your own combos lock you into long animations, while enemy windups are quick and barely telegraphed, so the only real way to block damage is by predicting their attacks. Some enemies don't stagger but still have giant sweeping attacks that can't be dodged, blocked, or jumped over. Not bosses, normal enemies. You WILL be taking a lot of damage, but recovery items are almost non existent. Food will very rarely drop from dead enemies, but will only ever restore about 2 or 3 hits worth of damage. You can and will get be getting juggled for twice that much.

The screen is constantly getting blocked, whether by enemies in the foreground, tall grass, stage clutter, or even just the boss being too big to see anything else behind him (such as all his friends winding up their attacks). One of the first levels in the game is a straight up rip of the infamous Battletoads sewer level, where you're on a speeding vehicle forced to react split second to shit flying at you from the right side of the screen. You're going to fail a lot. Then it immediately drops you into one of the worst controlled levels I have ever played in a video game, where you're floating in a river, barely able to move, unable to block, and only able to attack by jumping. But they keep throwing swarms of flying enemies at you, untouchable enemies shooting arrows from offscreen, giant fish who do unblockable charge attacks without windups, and bigass rocks that you still have to not run into or get knocked into by an enemy. The whole game is made with this kind of design philosophy.

This game is not fair. This game is not fun. Damage negation is a joke and there's almost no health recovery. Most of the players' tools don't work, and almost all of the enemies or obstacles are different flavors of bullshit that would never fly in modern games. Castle Crashers is a beloved classic because of the era it came out in, where riding a deer rocketing along from its own jet propelled shit stream with your friends was all you needed to think a game was entertaining. But more than a decade and a half later, those rose tinted glasses are putting in some serious work.

Castle Crashers seeks to give level-based brawler action with heavy multiplayer emphasis and "comedy". I can't help but cringe as I use that last word. Firstly, the mechanics are pretty solid and overall smooth. There are some exceptions:
-Vertical movement has the typical brawler problem of being 2x slower than horizontal, making it a chore
-Horizontal jumping doesn't keep enough momentum to feel tight
-Hitboxes feel a bit odd before you're used to them
-No actually good combo strings so attacks feel very basic and repetitive throughout the game

Otherwise, the controls and physics seem to pan out well. The graphical style is...2001 Newgrounds flash game. It's really quite bad and its only saving grace is that there are a few vector layers on each sprite for lights and shadow which flash games hadn't evolved yet. They opted for a more cartoonish storybook feel seemingly to fit the..."c-o-m-e-d-y" but it falls flat and feels like an excuse to be lazy.

Much of the humor in the game relies on poop, fart, college frat jokes and having women be creepily fought over for kisses...which they have seemingly no say in. The game includes many references to popular culture, which can rub many people the wrong way.

The game does enough to keep things fresh and alive by having many different knights with different powers, which you don't really get to use unless you put points into that special stat (whoops!). There are many findable secrets that include useful pets and weapons.

If you're looking for a couch co-op game with some secrets and difficulty, but don't care too much if it has flat humor and ugly visuals, give Crashers a try.

[h2]If you could relive your experience playing a game, what would that game be? [/h2]

It's a question asked occasionally to me that I usually say a different answer to whenever asked. Usually, it'd be the game I'm currently playing, or a hit game, such as Yakuza 0 or Ghost of Tsushima. But I felt that the games don't fulfill that quota. Sure, they tell compelling stories and I had fun playing them, but they're not actually the game I wanna relive my experience with. And then it hit me. It's not about what it means and how good a story or game it is, it's the experiences and fun you had with it that makes me want to relive the moment. I'm probably not explaining it well, so, let me put it this way; which would you remember more? A single player game, or a game that you played with friends that you get to share the experience with? That game for me was Castle Crashers. I remember when I was 8, sitting on the couch with my older brother, turning the Xbox 360 on. We'd sit there, controllers on our lap, as my brother navigated to the library to start up Castle Crashers. I miss that moment, if I'm gonna be honest. My brother is gone from this world, but that doesn't mean I can't share the fun I had with the world. So, if you are a person thinking of getting this game, my answer is a resounding yes. It's worth the money, it's great with friends, it's great solo. And you won't regret it.

Title: "Crusader's Quest: Castle Crashers Unveils its Holy Origins!"

Rating: ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê (5/5)

In an unexpected twist, the indie game sensation Castle Crashers has been revealed to be the brainchild of crusade apologists, blending medieval history with pixelated glory. As you embark on a quest to save princesses, little do you know that you're unraveling a secret tapestry of holy knights and divine pixels!

Graphics: ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê (5/5)
The game's art style takes you back to the glorious days of crusading, where knights donned shining armor and carried pixelated swords blessed by the divine. The attention to historical detail is unparalleled, showcasing the developers' commitment to a righteous aesthetic.

Gameplay: ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê (5/5)
Crusader's Quest seamlessly integrates holy relics and medieval combat, allowing players to engage in epic battles against hordes of foes. The divine powers bestowed upon the characters add an extra layer of strategy, proving that even in the pixelated realm, righteousness prevails.

Storyline: ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê (5/5)
Unravel the sacred tale of knights on a holy mission to save their kingdom from an evil wizard. The narrative brilliantly weaves together historical crusades with a touch of divine intervention, giving players a sense of purpose as they slash their way through enemies.

Soundtrack: ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê (5/5)
The heavenly melodies in Castle Crashers are a testament to the developers' commitment to authenticity. Each note resonates with the spirit of crusaders, transporting players to a time when chivalry and righteousness reigned supreme.

Overall, Castle Crashers provides an immersive experience that transcends the boundaries of time and space. Whether you're a history buff or just a pixel-loving gamer, this game will make you feel like a crusader on a holy quest. Praise pixelated glory!

One of the most fun and enjoyable games I've ever played! First played it on XBOX 360 in my youth, and played more on other consoles like Switch.

But I finally picked it up on Steam! I like being able to invite a friend to play the game with me, so I finally don't have to do it alone!

I've played through the campaign MAYBE one too many times (try more than 30 across consoles I've played it on), and what can I say? The gameplay is simple with some complexity to be learned if you want to get the most out of it, and the skill points assigned to stats when you level mean you can focus differently and have a different kind of playstyle for your run! Each knight's magic also has different elements, so you can experiment and find one that you like: be it the arrows and bombs of the Gray Knight or the ice magic from the Blue Knight to freeze enemies in place.

The story is pretty goofy and lighthearted: mainly just some laughs and enough of a reason to go through the stages. It will probably make you laugh at least once with some of the ridiculous moments that happen in the stages. And the music in the stages is top-notch, for every stage!

Maybe I'm just a little biased because I love the game so much. But I think it's worth the time to try for anyone who has some time to kill!

There is no words to describe how funny is this game, playing with friends o solo. The game is a blast and is probably one of the best things I played on Xbox. The game is very funny and it has an easy and hard mode, in case you already beat the game once.
You just have to run around with your character, which can be a crusader, a soldier, a barbarian, a skeleton, and more; while you are killing stuff and throwing spells to everything you find. Some times you find "vehicles" and other you can find specific pets that give you a bonus. Also, at specific points you can change your weapon for another one you find in battle or at specific places. The objective is saving the princesses of your kingdom.
I recommend to use a controller for this game. However, I played it myself some times on keyboard and is still good.
The game is 100% epic and funny and these 2 adjectives increase by 100% each time you add another player to the game. At some specific points all players battle between them to get specific bonuses, which make the game very funny and makes you wonder if you should spend your potion or keep it for the battle against your friends.
The game can be played for 2 players offline and the campaign can go to 4 total players online.

how to make delicious Butter Chicken.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Ingredients for 4 servings,
2 lb boneless, skinless chicken breast (910 g), cubed
salt, to taste
pepper, to taste
2 teaspoons chili powder, divided
¬Ω teaspoon turmeric
6 tablespoons butter, divided
1 ¬Ω cups yellow onion (225 g), diced
3 teaspoons garam masala
1 teaspoon cumin
1 teaspoon cayenne pepper
1 tablespoon ginger, grated
3 cloves garlic, minced
1 cinnamon, 3 inch (8 cm) stick
14 oz tomato sauce (395 g)
1 cup water (240 mL)
1 cup heavy cream (240 mL)
rice, for serving
fresh cilantro, chopped for garnish.

Preparation
In a large bowl, season the chicken breast with salt, pepper, 1 teaspoon of chili powder, and the teaspoon of turmeric. Let
sit for 15 minutes to marinate.
Melt 2 tablespoons of butter in a large pot over medium heat. Brown the chicken, then remove from the pot.
Melt another 2 tablespoons of butter in the pot, then add the onion, garam masala, remaining teaspoon of chili powder,
the cumin, ginger, garlic, cayenne, cinnamon, salt and pepper. Cook until fragrant.
Add the tomato sauce and bring to a simmer.
Add the water and cream and return to a simmer.
Return the chicken to the pot, cover, and simmer for another 10-15 minutes.
Stir in the last 2 tablespoons of butter and season with more salt and pepper to taste.
Serve the chicken over rice and garnish with cilantro.
Enjoy!

Other than my total praise (still 10/10), the Pc port has some minor issues with online Co-Op. Some being failure to connect with each other (uncommon), and the most common one (for me that is) is when playing online Co-Op there will be giant lag spikes where it feels like the game is running 1-10 fps but it's purely connection. Other than these 2 the game runs perfectly.

[b]> Be me
> Hear about Castle Crashers
> Think it's just a game about smashing castles
> Expect to play as a giant wrecking ball
> Install the game
> Realize it's about knights saving princesses
> WTF.jpg
> Choose a green knight because, well, it's green
> Game starts
> Friends join me
> We're all different colored knights
> Realize I'm the only one who picked green
> Suck it, traffic light squad!
> Start bashing bad guys
> Accidentally hit my friend
> He's a red knight
> "Sorry, bro. I'm just photosynthesizing over here."
> He's not amused
> Keep playing
> Find a pet
> It's a deer with an apple for a head
> Call it the "iDeer"
> Deer doesn't respond to Siri commands
> Disappointed
> Collect fruit and animal orbs
> Have a posse of critters following me
> Basically, I'm Snow White with a sword
> Get to a boss
> Gigantic catfish wearing a snorkel
> "I've heard of catfishing, but this is ridiculous."
> Beat the boss
> Friends cheer
> MFW they realize they can steal my animal orbs
> Suddenly, it's the Animal Orb Black Market
> I'm broke
> Take a break
> Realize I've been playing for 8 hours
> Castle Crashers: 10/10 would smash castles again [/b]

[i] Title: "Castle Crashers Critique by Shrek and Friends"

[Scene: Shrek, Donkey, Puss in Boots, Pinocchio, the Three Pigs, and the Gingerbread Man are gathered around a TV with controllers in their hands. Castle Crashers is loading on the screen.]

Shrek: (scratching his head) What's all this then? A game about smashing castles? Count me in!

Donkey: (excited) Oh, I hope I can be the dragon! I wanna be a flying donkey!

Puss in Boots: (looking at Donkey) Donkey, I assure you, you can't be the dragon. Calm down.

Pinocchio: (nervously) Can someone please tell me if lying in this game is a bad idea?

Three Pigs: (oinking) Let's huff and puff and smash some castles!

Gingerbread Man: (nervously) I hope we don't run into any gingerbread castles...

[The game starts, and they choose their characters.]

Shrek: (selecting the Green Knight) Naturally, I'm going to be the green one. Now, let's smash some castles!

Donkey: (choosing the Blue Knight) Blue is the color of royalty, right?

Puss in Boots: (selecting the Orange Knight) Orange is just as charming as I am.

Pinocchio: (picking the Red Knight) I hope my nose doesn't grow longer in the game.

Three Pigs: (each picking a different color) We'll cover all the bases, guys!

Gingerbread Man: (hesitating) Should I choose the Brown Knight? Nah, too risky. I'll go with the Gray Knight.

[They dive into the game, start bashing bad guys, and collecting items.]

Shrek: (smashing enemies) This is more fun than rescuing princesses! Sorry, Fiona.

Donkey: (kicking an enemy) Take that, you castle-wrecker!

Puss in Boots: (swinging his sword) I wish I had a little sombrero for my knight!

Pinocchio: (using magic) Hey, it's like playing Pin-the-Tail on the Castle.

Three Pigs: (laughing as they use weapons) Who needs bricks when you have swords?

Gingerbread Man: (throwing grenades) Catch my ginger grenades, you bready fiends!

[They encounter a giant boss, a catfish wearing a snorkel.]

Shrek: (laughing) A catfish? Must be Catfish Mignon!

Donkey: (singing) "Catfish in the sea, you and me, oh, how happy we'll be!"

Puss in Boots: (sword-dancing) I've always wanted to tango with a catfish!

Pinocchio: (shouting) Lie, you fish! I dare you!

Three Pigs: (oinking in unison) Let's turn this catfish into seafood!

Gingerbread Man: (tossing a ginger grenade) Eat this, you soggy fish!

[They defeat the boss and continue playing.]

Shrek: (counting loot) I've collected more stuff than in my swamp!

Donkey: (grinning) I'm the loot king! Who needs dragon treasure?

Puss in Boots: (gathering gems) I'm getting a gem-encrusted litter box after this.

Pinocchio: (with a growing nose) Oops, it's growing! I mean, my inventory, it's growing!

Three Pigs: (oinking with glee) We'll have a piggy feast tonight!

Gingerbread Man: (collecting icing) They say diamonds are a cookie's best friend!

[They finish the game.]

Shrek: (high-fiving) Well, that was a smashing good time!

Donkey: (laughing) It's a good thing we didn't run into any flying donkeys!

Puss in Boots: (posing) The only thing missing was a catnap power-up.

Pinocchio: (looking at his inventory) My nose didn't betray me! Yay!

Three Pigs: (belching) Oink, that was satisfying!

Gingerbread Man: (licking his icing) Sweet victory, mates!

[They all cheer and continue playing. Castle Crashers receives a unanimous thumbs up from the crew.] [/i]

Castle Crashers is a delightfully simplistic and enjoyable game that is best played alongside friends! The mechanics of the game are egregiously simple to the point it may feel rather boring at times, but that is easily overshadowed by the immense charm the game brings with it's lovely art style and sense of humor! The best way I may describe the game would be definitively Newgrounds. The achievements are also incredibly simple much like the game itself, leaving a relatively focused, but rewarding experience to 100%!

9/10 to play | 9/10 to complete

A positive surprise. The design and artistic side are very cool. The game runs smoothly, and the overall gameplay is fast-paced, which prevents boredom from setting in. All characters and bosses are unique, with very different and interesting attacks. There's also a grinding element present that's somewhat enjoyable, as it helped to keep interest up while not becoming too tedious. Speaking of difficulty, the story can be completed relatively easily, so those looking to add a bit spice to the overall experience, have the option to switch to "Insane Mode" after the first playthrough, which can be quite punishing.
Probably the only way you won't like this game is if you don't like 2D side-scrollers and/or hack-and-slash games at all.

I've played this far more on Xbox than on Steam, but this game is fantastic.
While it is technically a retro-game, it's aged like fine wine! The art holds up excellently, there are a huge number of well designed levels, the bosses feel unique and fun, the RPG upgrade and weapons feel varied enough, and the multi-player hack-and-slash chaos feels fun and relatively easy, but also allows for very clever and strategic battles if you want to try that rather than a brute-force hack-and-slash.

The controls are tight and intuitive, and it's a blast in single player or 2 - 4 player!

The only thing that might bother you is that you do have to grind a bit to level up and beat higher levels. It isn't an inordinate amount of grinding, but if you are hoping to just speed through to the end, that isn't going to happen.

A Whimsical Adventure Worth Every Second!
Castle Crashers is a game that not only brought back nostalgic memories but also created new ones. From the moment I started playing, I was captivated by its colorful and charming art style, quirky humor, and addictive gameplay.

The graphics in Castle Crashers are beautifully crafted, with each character and enemy having their unique charm and personality. The animations are smooth, and the vibrant world is a joy to explore. It's a testament to the game's timeless design that it still looks fantastic even years after its initial release.

The gameplay is where Castle Crashers truly shines. The controls are easy to pick up, making it accessible for players of all skill levels. But don't let the simplicity fool you; beneath the surface lies a depth of strategy that keeps you engaged throughout the entire adventure. Whether you're smashing enemies with your trusty weapon or unlocking new combos and magic spells, there's always something new to discover.

One of the most enjoyable aspects of Castle Crashers is its co-op mode. Playing with friends, either locally or online, is an absolute blast. Teaming up to defeat challenging bosses or competing to see who can collect the most gold adds an extra layer of fun and camaraderie to the game.

The humor and charm of Castle Crashers are also noteworthy. The quirky characters, humorous dialogue, and wacky scenarios had me laughing out loud multiple times. It's a rare game that can be both challenging and lighthearted, and Castle Crashers strikes that balance perfectly.

With a variety of characters to choose from, each with their own abilities and playstyles, Castle Crashers offers excellent replayability. You can experiment with different characters and strategies, ensuring that each playthrough feels fresh and exciting.

In conclusion, Castle Crashers is a timeless classic that has earned its place as one of the best indie games on Steam. Its delightful art style, addictive gameplay, and endless replayability make it a must-play for gamers of all ages. Whether you're a fan of beat 'em ups or just looking for a fun game to enjoy with friends, Castle Crashers has you covered.

I'm not a huge fan of the leveling system (you gain exp every time you hit an enemy as opposed to damage dealt, so people with lower damage will level much faster), but otherwise the game is great. I'd highly recommend playing Castle Crashers with a friend or three if you can, that's where the game really shines.

[h1] TLDR: 10/10 One of the most fun little indie games from the 360 era that continues to be a joy to play 15 years later. [/h1]

[b] Actual Review (No Spoilers): [/b] Yup. Castle Crashers still holds up all these years later thanks to a ton of replayability, a timeless art style, and goofy, fun-natured gameplay. I remember always wanted to play this game when I would visit my friend's house years back since I didn't have a 360, and it holds the same amount of charm today.

The game has a TON of unlockable content like characters, weapons, and pets. There's a lot of variety although admittedly not everything is useful or unique. A lot of characters are largely redundant, and a lot of the pets are pretty underpowered. That is basically my singular complaint with the game. But there's still enough there to spend countless hours trying them all out to see what is the most fun.

The combat is that of a beat-em-up and there is a surprising amount of depth to it. Juggling is by far one of the best parts of the combat, if you're good enough you can stay airborne for entire fights. The weapon selection is also really good. There's a weapon for any type of build. There is also a rebalance mod to use if you're wanting to make characters feel more unique from each other which also tweaks a bunch of other stuff to make everything more viable and fun to use.

The multiplayer is where you'll have the most fun. Up to 4 player co-op and it's always a chaotic mess. Sadly the online multiplayer is both pretty bad and pretty dead, but you can still plug in multiple controllers for couch co-op.

There are only 12 achievements to collect and the only grindy one is the arena master one where you have to win 40 online arena matches. Thankfully I was able to find someone to grind it with on the discussion forums. All other achievements will come pretty naturally aside from one or two.

Castle Crashers is a game that truly exemplifies the sheer joy of gaming, and I mean HOLY is this game good. Its vibrant, hand-drawn visuals draw you into a whimsical world filled with knights, princesses, and an assortment of bizarre foes. The action-packed gameplay keeps you on your toes as you battle through waves of enemies, leveling up your character, and unlocking a plethora of weapons and magical abilities. The game's cooperative mode is where it truly shines, allowing you to team up with friends for some chaotic and hilarious adventures. Whether you're smiting bosses or rescuing adorable animals, the game keeps you engaged with its relentless charm and entertaining combat.

What sets Castle Crashers apart is its ability to strike a balance between accessibility and depth, making it a game that both casual and hardcore gamers can appreciate. The soundtrack, a delightful cacophony of catchy tunes, further enhances the overall experience. In the world of indie gaming, Castle Crashers stands tall as a testament to creativity, humor, and fantastic game design, and I mean HOLY is this game good.

I used to play the demo version of castle crashers on my 360 back in 2009. Finally getting to play the full game on a 1080p monitor instead of a 720p tv was a blast! If you're wanting to play this game how it was meant to be played, use a controller. Now if you wanted to play this game like it was MEANT and I mean MEANT to be played, get one of those wired xbox 360 controllers, if you can find one. Alternatively buy the hyperkin xenon controller, it's a licensed by xbox controller which is basically a 1:1 replica of the original wired xbox 360 controller. Oh yeah I should probably review the game huh. This game is what you expect, classic level based beat em' up. Every knight has different magic abilities (oh yeah there's magic too) so make sure to research which knight you want to take if you really care about magic (melee gang ftw). What else is there to say about this game really? If you didn't grow up with it, I highly recommend you pick up this game even if it's not on sale. It's not everyone's cup of tea but the simplicity of this game really makes it more enjoyable than most games released today, simple premise, simple end goal. If you're into that stuff by all means check out this gem of a game. If not, I'm honestly not sure why you're even still reading this review to be honest, just go buy elden ring or whatever.

Normally I don't review games but this game is an old relic, and I strongly recommend it. It's over fifteen years old and I'd say it's still the same great gem that it used to be. Be warned that this game is very much meant for more than one player! But don't worry, you wont have to buy a second or third copy if you're in the same place. All you need are controllers, and you're good to go!

My time on this computer is only 17.2  hours. But back in the day I know I had roughly 100 hours at least on the Xbox 360. I've revisited it recently to see if it's as good as I remember, and I can proudly say it was. Admittedly this is very much a product of it's time, but it's still decently funny and extremely fun even after 15 years.

The game runs extremely smoothly. I'm very used to playing games with annoying loading menus but Castle Crashers is an extremely seamless experience. The levels are long but not too long, and if you die halfway through you can pick up right where you left off, and also replay levels from that point. 

I wouldn't say any level is extremely tedious, though it can be a bit difficult. There have been maybe one or two things that I'd deem as too annoying, but the grind through it is far from awful. The game also doesn't hold your hand, and you get thrown into things immediately. You also have to pick up mechanics on the fly. But honestly the games control scheme is so easy to pick up at first that you should learn quickly how to at least survive your first encounter. 
I think the only parts I've really disliked are the water one, and escaping the alien ship. But honestly, the former is easy enough once you learn how to beat it, and the latter just takes a few goes through. (Plus the end of that level is very funny, to me!) Also there's some minor issues with aiming at things and the Y-axis, but honestly that's just something you get used to.

There are a lot of secrets and the game encourages you to run through it again/backtrack with new items, since you can get pets or weapons that were previously unavailable to you. There are some mini-games in levels that break up game play, which I enjoy.

Like I mentioned before this is absolutely a game to play with the fellas. Thankfully it has local play, so you just need to hook up some controllers to your computer and you're good to go. You cannot change the control scheme which sucks, but I find the control scheme to be fine enough. The absolute relief I felt when the game just picked up the two controllers with no fuss was immense.

My Castle Crashers review

The positives

+Fun artstyle
+Combat is quite enjoyable and there's a good amount of weapons and playstyles
+Co-op works well
+Good soundtrack

The negatives

-Juvenile humor
-Unbalanced builds
-Harder difficulties are way too difficult

Score: 8.6/10

Had this game across several platforms since around 2014. In terms of playtime, it doesn't take long to beat the game, which is both a good thing and a bad thing. It makes the game easy to replay over and over, whether that's for new characters or just to play the game some more. However, runthroughs typically last somewhere around 4 hours at a moderate pace. The cost of the game versus replayability is 100% fair in my opinion and I love the game so much that I've bought plenty of merch from the Behemoth store to show support and rep the cool designs.

am a 51 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 30 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he friended and invited me to join him. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Castle Crashers is a game that's both short and sweet. If you want a cozy / simplistic game to play through with others, or alone like I did, that has cheeky lowbrow humor, this game is for you. The RPG elements are basic, and for a beat 'em up, that's perfectly fitting. On top of that, there is plenty of characters to choose with varing magic abilities and quirks to them to encourage replaying the game. The environments and assets are all uniquely drawn and stand out. There is so many memorable locations and enemy / boss designs in this game. My only complaint is that if you're playing solo, you are definitely going to have to grind for a few levels here and there, but it's just not so excessive that I felt like it was a serious subtractor to the game itself. In conclusion, I'd say it's worth your money if you are looking for any of the qualities above, especially on sale since it goes for real cheap.

A 4 player co-op hack and slash by The Behemoth (Battleblock Theater, Alien Hominid). The game follows the comical adventures of four knights as they try to defeat a dark wizard and rescue four princesses.

The game looks like a 2004 flash animation with charmingly simple cartoony graphics and it plays about as complex as one too. You have light, heavy, ranged, and magic attacks but they aren't employed in any tactical way. You eventually unlock combos as you level up but otherwise it plays like an old school side scrolling brawler (ala Streets of Rage).

The story is minimal and very silly. Each stage has it's own jokes as you hunt down the dark wizard and face off against his various minions. It's not a very deep game but my god is it a grind as it goes on and on. If you're playing with friends there's a bit more to it but as a single player adventure it just drags and you'll have to grind levels at points to get past later stages due to linear difficulty.

There's some collectibles, cosmetics, and reskined characters to unlock, but those are only for the truly dedicated. If you want a simple silly adventure it's cheap and plentiful but it's so basic it has trouble sustaining a playthrough.

Castle Crashers is a wonderful game with an amazing art style, great soundtrack, funny characters, and exciting combat. It's got a ton of content, the boss battles are fun and usually somewhat difficult, and the difficulty system of the game is very well balanced in my opinion. I originally played the Xbox 360 edition several years ago and although that game was good, this version has been remastered to include very important changes such as tweaking the prices of shop items. 

I really enjoy playing this game solo, but it's even better if you can get a few friends together and play. Not only does it lower the difficulty a bit through the resuscitation system (which allows other players to revive you if you die), the hours of fun and crazy excitement that you will get from this game will be completely worth it.

I highly recommend Castle Crashers at any price. The DLCs are also decent, and I enjoy the characters that come with them. Since they're at a very reasonable price, I would recommend buying them if you have the spare cash. If you don't buy them though, that's okay, as there are many other characters in the game that are either available by default or unlocked through gameplay.

Here is a bedtime story instead of a review





Once upon a time, in a magical kingdom nestled deep within an enchanted forest, there lived a curious little rabbit named Oliver. Oliver was no ordinary rabbit. He had the ability to speak with all the creatures of the forest and had a heart filled with an insatiable desire for adventure.

One moonlit night, as the stars twinkled above, Oliver couldn't fall asleep. He hopped out of his cozy burrow and ventured into the forest, hoping to find something exciting to do. As he hopped along the winding path, he stumbled upon a shimmering light emanating from a hidden glade.

Curiosity overwhelmed Oliver, and he hopped closer, discovering a group of woodland animals gathered in a circle. At the center stood a wise old owl named Orville, known for his infinite knowledge and captivating storytelling. The animals sat in awe as Orville began to recount a tale of a lost treasure hidden deep within the forest.

Oliver's eyes widened with excitement, and he knew in his heart that he had to embark on a grand quest to find this treasure. He shared his intentions with Orville, who encouraged him and offered guidance. The owl explained that the treasure was guarded by three challenges, each requiring bravery, wisdom, and kindness.

With newfound determination, Oliver set off on his adventure. The first challenge awaited him at the Crystal Caves, a labyrinth of gleaming crystals that shimmered like stars. Oliver navigated the twisting passages, relying on his intuition and cleverness to find the way. Finally, he reached the heart of the cave, where a massive boulder blocked his path. Remembering the wisdom of the owl, Oliver channeled all his strength and pushed with all his might. With a loud rumble, the boulder gave way, revealing a hidden passage.

The second challenge led Oliver to the Whispering Woods, where magical trees whispered ancient secrets. As he wandered through the forest, he encountered a lost fox cub, frightened and alone. Oliver, showing his kindness, comforted the cub and helped it find its way back to its family. In gratitude, the trees whispered directions to the next challenge‚Äîthe Tower of Wisdom.

The Tower of Wisdom stood tall and majestic, reaching toward the sky. Oliver climbed the stairs, his heart pounding with anticipation. At the top, he faced a wise old turtle who posed a riddle. The riddle tested Oliver's intellect and problem-solving skills. With careful thought and reasoning, Oliver solved the riddle, impressing the turtle with his cleverness.

Finally, Oliver arrived at the secret location of the hidden treasure‚Äîa sparkling waterfall in the heart of the forest. He gazed at the shimmering water, feeling a sense of accomplishment and pride. But instead of claiming the treasure for himself, he realized that true happiness came from sharing and spreading joy.

Oliver returned to the glade, bringing all the forest animals together to witness the unveiling of the treasure. As he pulled back the curtain of leaves, a burst of radiant light emerged‚Äîa magical fountain that granted the wishes of those who believed in kindness and unity.

From that day forward, the animals of the forest lived in harmony, their wishes granted by the enchanted fountain. And Oliver, the brave and selfless rabbit, became a cherished hero, guiding others toward kindness, wisdom, and the true treasure of a loving heart.

As the animals settled down for the night, Oliver's tale lingered in their hearts, reminding them of the power of courage, compassion, and the magic that resides within each and every one of us. And with dreams filled with hope and wonder, they drifted off to sleep, knowing that tomorrow would bring new adventures and possibilities in their enchanted forest home.

100% Review

Castle Crashers will forever hold a special place in my heart, as I first played it on the Xbox 360, and finally being able to play it again on Steam was a dream come true. There is so much to say about this game, the art style and graphics are, and will be forever charming and fun, the locations and enemies are very diverse, providing a unique and captivating experience the whole way through, and the gameplay is surprisingly smooth for it's time; Learning combos and other crazy ways to juggle enemies is some of the most fun I've ever had in a game. Playing with friends is extremely fun as well (Especially when you're 20 levels ahead of them). The game has plenty of secret unlockables and side content to keep you busy as well, such as the slew of unlockable characters, and the Back-Off-Barbarian gamemode.  I do have a couple complaints though, the "Insane Mode", an optional mode you earn after completing the game, is complete garbage. It bloats the enemy's health and damage by an almost comical amount, which makes for a MISERABLE experience. Another complaint isn't really the game's fault, more the passage of time's; The online community is pretty much completely dead, which is a shame considering how much fun the arena game mode could be. Overall though, Castle Crashers is a fantastic side-scrolling beat-em-up that I cannot recommend more, it's fun throughout the whole game and offers a unique experience that I'm sure will pass the test of time.

I don't have nearly as many hours as I did on PS3, but I love the game, I played on PS3 about 8 years ago and still love the game today, if you are looking for a fun beat-em-up to play alone or with friends, play Castle Crashers. (blue knight best, only ever played him)

While keeping the charisma and sketchiness of its predecessor Alien Hominid HD, the game is a lot more polished when it comes to artstyle, and gets the animation a bit more conservative.

As complex as any beat 'em up, castle crashers of course achieves a feeling of bad-assery (if that is even a thing) as competent as the one you would get with Devil May Cry or God of War, I especially highlight this feeling in bossfights with equals like the cyclops, the necromancer and the wizard (if that was his name lmao); all of this even though the game is comedic enough, proving itself as a tough, while not infuriating challenge, unless we talk about insane mode, that shit is from another world.

In-game collectibles generally work out well thanks to the lack of quality distinction between one another, in the case of weapons, while there is some representation of progression with some weapons, in the late game the choice becomes a matter of playstyle and choosing an aesthetic; on the other hand, pets, the other collectible, give all very different abilities that ultimately come down to the situation where they are more appropiate; inventory elements like the bow, the boomerang and others are all extremely distinct and have no point of comparison, constituting fundamentala features of gameplay each of them.

In case the collectibles didn't suggest enough that this game has insane replay-value, the playable characters will: in the base game you have the four knights with different magic powers and some variation in statistics, the steam version also includes the alien from Alien Hominid since this one is, unfortunately, not available in steam; you get plenty new characters on your first playthrough thanks to some feats you will do in order to beat it, or some you CAN do if you are skilled enough, like completing arenas of each region. Beating the game with each base knight unlocks four new characters, which, in turn, unlock another four; long story short, if you get into the replay world of this game, you're not getting out any time soon.

Castle Crashers is, finally, one of the most memorable couch-coop experiences you will ever get, and experiencing its multiplayer is practically mandatory if you want to get the full flavor of it.

Castle Crashers, developed by The Behemoth, is an absolute triumph of cooperative beat 'em up gaming that seamlessly combines delightful visuals, addictive gameplay, hilarious humor, and a captivating multiplayer experience. From the moment I embarked on this whimsical adventure, I was enchanted by its charm and entertained to the fullest extent. Castle Crashers is a shining example of what makes gaming an exhilarating and joyful experience.

Let's start with the game's delightful visuals. The hand-drawn art style is vibrant, colorful, and packed with personality. Each character, enemy, and location is meticulously crafted with a unique and eye-catching design. The animations are fluid and lively, bringing the world of Castle Crashers to life with an infectious energy. The attention to detail is astounding, and the visual presentation alone is enough to immerse players in a world that is both adorable and action-packed.

The gameplay in Castle Crashers is nothing short of addictive. The controls are tight, responsive, and intuitive, allowing for seamless combat and navigation. The variety of playable characters, each with their own distinct abilities and playstyles, adds depth and replayability. The progression system, as you level up your character and unlock new skills and weapons, provides a rewarding sense of growth and customization. The combat mechanics are satisfyingly fluid, with a wide range of combo moves and special attacks that make each encounter a thrilling and strategic affair. Whether playing solo or with friends, the gameplay of Castle Crashers offers endless hours of fun and excitement.

Speaking of friends, Castle Crashers truly shines in its multiplayer experience. The game seamlessly supports local and online cooperative play, allowing up to four players to join forces on this epic adventure. The joy of teaming up with friends or strangers to conquer hordes of enemies, rescue princesses, and engage in epic boss battles is an unparalleled experience. The laughter, camaraderie, and shared victories make Castle Crashers an absolute blast to play in a group. The game fosters a sense of cooperation and teamwork, and the excitement of coordinating attacks and combining abilities with your allies is immensely satisfying.

Another standout aspect of Castle Crashers is its fantastic sense of humor. The game is filled with witty dialogue, clever pop culture references, and absurd moments that consistently deliver laughs. From the quirky characters you encounter to the hilarious boss battles and bizarre situations, Castle Crashers keeps the player entertained with its whimsical and often unexpected humor. It adds an extra layer of enjoyment to the already stellar gameplay and showcases the developers' talent for creating an engaging and lighthearted experience.

Furthermore, Castle Crashers boasts an impressive amount of content. The game features a robust campaign with multiple levels and branching paths, ensuring that players have a lengthy and rewarding journey ahead. Additionally, the inclusion of various game modes, such as Arena battles and Insane Mode, extends the replay value and offers new challenges for those seeking even more excitement.

In conclusion, Castle Crashers is a masterclass in cooperative beat 'em up gaming. Its delightful visuals, addictive gameplay, hilarious humor, and seamless multiplayer experience combine to create an unforgettable adventure. Whether playing solo or with friends, the game provides endless hours of joy, laughter, and thrilling combat. Castle Crashers is a true gem in the gaming world, showcasing the magic that can happen when talented developers pour their hearts into creating a game that is brimming with creativity and fun. Prepare to embark on a majestic journey that will leave you with a permanent smile on your face.

This is one of the best if not the best video game at presenting poop joke. The developers have put a lot of attention and care into the poop jokes of this game, they are sublime, well-thought, and well-executed, with in-depth lore that can only be put together by a person who have mastered the art of poop jokery. The poop joke are repeated atleast five times throughout the game, with each poop joke making the player crave for more poop joke. The poop itself has a striking quality compared to the rest of the game, it has the perfect artstyle, coloring, shading, and sound design with just the right tempo, pitch, and duration, making it perfect for the ideal poop joke. All these qualities will make it hard for any player to miss on experiencing the most cutting-edge and immersive poop jokes, which makes for a memorable experience and enjoyable gameplay.

Unless you're a masochist like me, the only fun you'll get out of this is on your first few playthroughs unless you have friends, which if you do good job, but there is simply too much about this game that is stacked so high with so many levels of poor design choices that I genuinely question why anyone, including myself, is willing to do more than a few playthroughs. Some say it's a skill issue and that's why it seems unfair so often to me, none of those who say that (so far) have actually played the game after defeating the final boss on normal for the first time either, but I think even the most die hard fans would probably agree that there are a lot of questionable decisions and glitchy mechanics. If you have friends interested in this game it can be a hell of a time, but if you're mostly alone, you're best off finding something with more content than a single campaign that you can do as incredibly easy or unreasonably difficult to anyone who hasn't mastered every corner of the castle, a couple pets, and a few dozen weapons and playable characters. Have fun, if possible.

What a classic.
I originally played this game years and years ago on the Xbox 360 and as a kid loved every second of it, as I've grown older I still enjoy parts of this game whilst some of it just bogs me down.

I'll start with the pros, the game runs incredibly smooth, the Steam version has great graphics, all the achievements work, and I never encountered any game-breaking bugs!

The cons include very VERY repetitive game play, which while some may enjoy it just didn't sit well with me after all these years.

You can level up your character to build their stats up and make them stronger and the game does a really great job at balancing those skill-sets while you progress during your first play through, the developers encourage replay-ability by having you unlock new characters, and the kicker there is once you start a new game with a new character the whole campaign is reset for that said character. That sort of repetitiveness to me just isn't enjoyable.

I enjoyed playing with friends but I sadly would not recommend the game if you're playing solo.
Multiplayer works and is either co-op campaign or PvP mini games that feel old after a few rounds.

Overall I recommend the game from a creativity, soundtrack, overall feel, and polished standpoint,
I just can't recommend playing the whole game and achievement hunting without friends to play with and back you up.

Yabba dabba doo! Gather 'round, folks, 'cause I'm here to give you the lowdown on Castle Crashers, Flintstone-style! Get ready to rock in this prehistoric adventure!

Let me tell ya, Castle Crashers is like a brontosaurus-sized feast of fun! It's a stone-age extravaganza where you get to play as mighty warriors on a quest to rescue the fair maidens, just like when Fred saved Wilma from danger!

The visuals in this game are as vibrant as a bedrock sunset. The colorful landscapes and zany characters will make you feel like you're walking through the streets of Bedrock itself. You'll encounter cavemen, dinosaurs, and all sorts of wacky creatures on your way.

The gameplay is as thrilling as racing down a volcano on a boulder! You'll swing your clubs and throw stones to defeat enemies, just like when Fred and Barney went bowling. You can team up with your pals for some dino-sized co-op action, just like Fred and Barney teaming up for a game of golf.

Each level is packed with surprises, just like the time Fred and Barney got caught in a landslide of laughs. You'll face fierce boss battles that will test your strength and skill, like wrestling a T-Rex. It's a stone-cold challenge, but you can do it!

The humor in Castle Crashers will have you laughing harder than when Fred slid down the tail of a dinosaur. The silly antics and slapstick comedy will make you feel like you're part of a Flintstones episode. You'll giggle, chuckle, and have a grand old time.

Now, keep in mind, this game may not have the latest dinosaur-powered technology, but it's got that old-school charm that'll make your heart go "yabba dabba doo!" It's a blast from the past that'll transport you back to the stone age.

In conclusion, Castle Crashers is a rockin' good time, just like a Bedrock BBQ! It's got caveman style, prehistoric pizzazz, and enough fun to make even Fred Flintstone proud. So grab your clubs, gather your friends, and get ready for a dino-sized adventure that'll have you shouting, "Wilmaaaaaa!"

This is one of the best if not the best video game at presenting poop joke. The developers have put a lot of attention and care into the poop jokes of this game, they are sublime, well-thought, and well-executed, with in-depth lore that can only be put together by a person who have mastered the art of poop jokery. The poop joke are repeated atleast five times throughout the game, with each poop joke making the player crave for more poop joke. The poop itself has a striking quality compared to the rest of the game, it has the perfect artstyle, coloring, shading, and sound design with just the right tempo, pitch, and duration, making it perfect for the ideal poop joke. All these qualities will make it hard for any player to miss on experiencing the most cutting-edge and immersive poop jokes, which makes for a memorable experience and enjoyable gameplay.
